broccoli.name: Broccoli, raw
broccoli.insight: A nutritional powerhouse—exceptional vitamin C and K with cancer-fighting sulforaphane. One of the most nutrient-dense foods on Earth.

balanced.insight: Exceptional nutrient density with high fiber, vitamins C and K, and very low calories. Hard to beat.

heart_health.insight: Stellar potassium (288mg), fiber, and virtually no sodium. Sulforaphane compounds support arterial health.

muscle_building.insight: 2.5g protein is decent for a vegetable but won't build muscle. Great side dish to pair with protein sources.

energy.insight: Good B-vitamins and iron for energy metabolism. Low-GI carbs provide steady fuel without crashes.
cons: Low total calories for energy needs

weight_management.insight: Only 31 calories per cup with 2.4g fiber = exceptional satiety per calorie. A dieter's best friend.

brain_focus.insight: High antioxidants (vitamin C, sulforaphane) protect brain cells. Good folate supports cognition.

gut_health.insight: 2.4g fiber per cup plus prebiotic compounds support a healthy microbiome. Sulforaphane may benefit gut lining.
cons: Can cause gas in some people

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 15 is extremely low. High fiber, minimal sugar (1.5g). Perfect for blood sugar management.

bone_joint.insight: Excellent vitamin K (92.5mcg, 103% DV) crucial for bone protein synthesis. Good calcium and vitamin C for collagen.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Sulforaphane is a potent anti-inflammatory compound. High antioxidants, no omega-6 concerns. Top tier.

iron.tip: Already contains vitamin C to aid absorption

calcium.tip: Oxalates are low in broccoli, so calcium absorbs well

pairWith.reason: Fat helps absorb fat-soluble vitamins A, E, K
Combined anti-inflammatory compounds enhance benefits
Complete the meal with lean protein

broccoli.portionVisual: 1 cup = about the size of a baseball

tips.storage: Refrigerate unwashed in a loose bag for up to 5 days
tips.cooking: Lightly steam (3-4 min) to preserve nutrients; avoid boiling
tips.prepTip: Chop and let sit 5 min before cooking to maximize sulforaphane

commonMistakes: Overcooking destroys vitamin C and sulforaphane
Boiling leaches water-soluble nutrients into water

cautions.warfarin: High vitamin K—maintain consistent intake if on blood thinners
cautions.thyroid: Goitrogens may affect thyroid if eaten raw in large amounts

broccoli.pregnancyNotes: Excellent choice—high folate supports fetal development

drugInteractions.reason: Vitamin K affects blood clotting—keep intake consistent

broccoli_cooked.name: Broccoli, cooked
broccoli_cooked.insight: Cooking concentrates nutrients—even higher vitamin K, folate, and fiber than raw. Steaming preserves most benefits.

balanced.insight: Cooking concentrates nutrients—exceptional vitamin K (244% DV), folate (42% DV), and fiber (5.1g).
cons: Slightly reduced vitamin C from cooking

heart_health.insight: Outstanding potassium (457mg), fiber (5.1g), and virtually no sodium. Ideal for cardiovascular health.

muscle_building.insight: 3.7g protein is better than raw but still insufficient alone. Excellent micronutrients for recovery.

energy.insight: Enhanced B-vitamins from cooking support energy metabolism. Good iron and magnesium.

weight_management.insight: Only 55 calories with 5.1g fiber = exceptional satiety. High volume, high water content.

brain_focus.insight: Exceptional folate (168mcg) crucial for cognition. High antioxidants protect brain cells.

gut_health.insight: 5.1g fiber per cup is outstanding. Prebiotic compounds feed beneficial gut bacteria.
cons: May cause gas in sensitive individuals

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 15, high fiber (5.1g), minimal sugar (2.2g). Exceptional for blood sugar control.

bone_joint.insight: Outstanding vitamin K (220mcg, 244% DV) essential for bone protein synthesis. Good calcium.

anti_inflammatory.insight: High sulforaphane, excellent vitamin C (101mg). One of the most anti-inflammatory foods available.

iron.tip: High vitamin C content enhances iron absorption

calcium.tip: Cooking reduces oxalates, improving calcium bioavailability

pairWith.reason: Fat enhances absorption of vitamins A, E, K
Vitamin C further boosts iron absorption
Complete meal with omega-3 and protein

broccoli_cooked.portionVisual: 1 cup = about the size of a baseball

tips.storage: Refrigerate cooked broccoli for up to 3 days in airtight container
tips.cooking: Steam 5-7 minutes for best nutrient retention; avoid boiling
tips.prepTip: Add lemon juice after cooking to preserve color and boost iron absorption

commonMistakes: Overcooking makes it mushy and destroys nutrients
Boiling leaches vitamins into water

cautions.warfarin: Very high vitamin K—maintain consistent intake if on blood thinners
cautions.thyroid: Cooking reduces goitrogens but don't eat huge amounts if hypothyroid

broccoli_cooked.pregnancyNotes: Excellent choice—outstanding folate (42% DV) supports fetal development

drugInteractions.reason: Very high vitamin K affects blood clotting—keep intake consistent

spinach.name: Spinach, cooked
spinach.insight: One of the most nutrient-dense foods on Earth—exceptional vitamin K (987% DV), iron, folate, and magnesium. Popeye was right.

balanced.insight: Off-the-charts nutrient density. Exceptional iron (36% DV), folate (66% DV), vitamin K (987% DV), magnesium (37% DV).

heart_health.insight: Outstanding potassium (839mg), magnesium (157mg), and nitrates that support blood pressure and arterial health.

muscle_building.insight: 5.4g protein is excellent for a vegetable. Nitrates may improve exercise performance and muscle oxygen delivery.

energy.insight: Outstanding iron (6.4mg, 36% DV) crucial for oxygen transport. Excellent B-vitamins and magnesium for ATP production.

weight_management.insight: Only 41 calories with 5.4g protein and 4.3g fiber. Exceptional satiety and nutrient density.

brain_focus.insight: Exceptional folate (263mcg, 66% DV) and nitrates support cognition and blood flow to brain. High antioxidants.

gut_health.insight: 4.3g fiber plus prebiotic compounds support microbiome. Magnesium aids digestive motility.

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 15, minimal sugar (0.8g), high fiber. Nitrates may improve insulin sensitivity. Perfect for diabetics.

bone_joint.insight: Extraordinary vitamin K (888mcg, 987% DV) crucial for bone protein synthesis. Excellent calcium and magnesium.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Exceptional antioxidants, high vitamin E, excellent omega-3:6 ratio (5.7:1). Strong anti-inflammatory profile.

iron.tip: Pair with vitamin C (citrus, tomatoes) to boost absorption. Cooking helps.

calcium.tip: High oxalates bind calcium—only ~5% absorbs. Not a primary calcium source.

pairWith.reason: Vitamin C dramatically boosts iron absorption
Fat helps absorb vitamins A, E, K
Enhances anti-inflammatory benefits

spinach.portionVisual: 1 cup cooked = about the size of a baseball (cooks down from ~6 cups raw)

tips.storage: Refrigerate fresh spinach for 3-5 days; cooked for 3 days
tips.cooking: Lightly steam or sauté to preserve nutrients; cooking reduces volume 90%
tips.prepTip: Add acid (lemon, vinegar) after cooking to preserve bright green color

commonMistakes: Not pairing with vitamin C to boost iron absorption
Relying on it for calcium (oxalates block absorption)

cautions.kidneyStones: Very high oxalates—avoid if prone to calcium oxalate kidney stones
cautions.warfarin: Extremely high vitamin K—maintain consistent intake if on blood thinners
cautions.gout: Contains purines—moderate intake if prone to gout

spinach.pregnancyNotes: Excellent choice—outstanding folate (66% DV) and iron support fetal development

drugInteractions.reason: Extremely high vitamin K affects blood clotting—keep intake very consistent
May slightly interfere with absorption—separate by 2-4 hours

spinach_raw.name: Spinach, raw
spinach_raw.insight: Nutrient-dense raw greens—excellent vitamin K (161% DV) and folate. Raw preserves vitamin C but cooking concentrates other nutrients.

balanced.insight: Outstanding nutrient density for only 7 calories. Excellent vitamin K (161% DV), good folate (15% DV) and iron.

heart_health.insight: Good potassium, virtually no sodium, and nitrates that support blood pressure. Zero saturated fat.

muscle_building.insight: Only 0.9g protein per cup raw. Nitrates may help performance but insufficient protein alone.

energy.insight: Good iron (0.8mg) and some B-vitamins, but you'd need to eat a lot. Better cooked for energy needs.

weight_management.insight: Only 7 calories per cup! You can eat massive volumes for minimal calories. Perfect for volume eating.

brain_focus.insight: Good folate (58mcg) and nitrates support brain blood flow. Raw preserves vitamin C for antioxidants.

gut_health.insight: 0.7g fiber per cup is decent for raw greens. Raw enzymes may benefit digestion but can irritate some.
cons: Need large volume for significant fiber

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 15, almost no sugar (0.1g), good fiber. Perfect for blood sugar control.

bone_joint.insight: Excellent vitamin K (145mcg, 161% DV) for bone protein synthesis. Calcium present but poorly absorbed due to oxalates.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Raw preserves maximum antioxidants and vitamin C. Excellent omega-3:6 ratio (5.7:1). Very anti-inflammatory.

iron.tip: Pair with vitamin C (citrus) or cook to improve absorption

calcium.tip: Oxalates bind calcium—cooking reduces oxalates and improves absorption

pairWith.reason: Vitamin C boosts iron absorption in salads
Fat helps absorb vitamins A, E, K
Healthy fats enhance nutrient absorption

spinach_raw.portionVisual: 1 cup raw = about the size of a baseball (very light, only 30g)

tips.storage: Refrigerate unwashed in a loose bag for 3-5 days; wash just before use
tips.cooking: Add to salads raw or wilt into dishes at the end of cooking
tips.prepTip: Massage with lemon juice to tenderize and reduce bitterness

commonMistakes: Not washing thoroughly (can harbor dirt and bacteria)
Expecting it to be a primary calcium source (oxalates block absorption)

cautions.kidneyStones: High oxalates—avoid if prone to calcium oxalate kidney stones
cautions.warfarin: High vitamin K—maintain consistent intake if on blood thinners
cautions.foodSafety: Wash thoroughly—spinach is high-risk for E. coli contamination

spinach_raw.pregnancyNotes: Good folate (15% DV) but wash very thoroughly to avoid foodborne illness

drugInteractions.reason: High vitamin K affects blood clotting—keep intake consistent

carrot.name: Carrot, raw
carrot.insight: A beta-carotene superstar—one carrot provides 104% DV of vitamin A for vision and immune health. Crunchy, portable, perfect snack.

balanced.insight: Exceptional vitamin A (509mcg, 104% DV) from beta-carotene. Good fiber, very low calorie, naturally sweet.

heart_health.insight: Good potassium (195mg), fiber (1.7g), and beta-carotene antioxidants support cardiovascular health.

muscle_building.insight: Only 0.6g protein and 25 calories. Not for muscle building—just a crunchy snack.

energy.insight: Natural sugars (2.9g) provide quick energy. Beta-carotene supports immune function but limited B-vitamins.

weight_management.insight: Only 25 calories with satisfying crunch and fiber. Perfect low-calorie snack that curbs hunger.

brain_focus.insight: Exceptional beta-carotene antioxidants protect brain cells. Limited B-vitamins but good for neuroprotection.

gut_health.insight: 1.7g fiber plus pectin (a prebiotic fiber) feeds beneficial gut bacteria. Raw crunch aids digestion.

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 35 is low. Fiber (1.7g) slows sugar absorption despite natural sweetness (2.9g sugar). Good choice.

bone_joint.insight: Vitamin A supports bone remodeling but low in calcium, vitamin D, and K. Not a bone-health superstar.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Excellent beta-carotene antioxidants fight inflammation. Good ORAC score. Low omega-3 but minimal omega-6.

vitaminA.tip: Beta-carotene absorbs better with fat—dip in hummus or eat with nuts

pairWith.reason: Fat enhances beta-carotene absorption
Cooking with fat increases vitamin A absorption up to 6x
Healthy fats boost nutrient absorption

carrot.portionVisual: 1 medium carrot = about the length of your hand

tips.storage: Refrigerate in a plastic bag for up to 3 weeks; remove greens if attached
tips.cooking: Eat raw for crunch or cook to increase beta-carotene bioavailability
tips.prepTip: Peel only if dirty—most nutrients are near the skin

commonMistakes: Eating without fat (limits vitamin A absorption)
Over-peeling removes nutrients near skin

cautions.carotenemia: Eating excessive amounts can turn skin orange (harmless but cosmetic)
cautions.allergies: Rare but can cross-react with birch pollen allergies

carrot.pregnancyNotes: Excellent—vitamin A supports fetal development. Don't overconsume (>10,000 IU/day can be harmful).

pediatric.ageAppropriate: 6+ months (cooked and pureed), 12+ months (raw sticks with supervision)
pediatric.chokingRisk: moderate raw—cut into thin sticks, supervise closely

carrots.name: Carrots, raw
carrots.insight: A beta-carotene powerhouse—one cup provides 218% DV of vitamin A for vision and immune health. Crunchy, naturally sweet, nutrient-dense.

balanced.insight: Exceptional vitamin A (1069mcg, 218% DV) from beta-carotene. Good fiber (3.6g), very low calorie, naturally sweet.

heart_health.insight: Good potassium (410mg), fiber (3.6g), and beta-carotene antioxidants support cardiovascular health.

muscle_building.insight: Only 1.2g protein and 52 calories. Not for muscle building—just a healthy side or snack.

energy.insight: Natural sugars (6.1g) provide quick energy. Beta-carotene supports immune function but limited B-vitamins.

weight_management.insight: Only 52 calories per cup with satisfying crunch and fiber (3.6g). Perfect low-calorie snack or side.

brain_focus.insight: Exceptional beta-carotene antioxidants protect brain cells. Limited B-vitamins but good for neuroprotection.

gut_health.insight: 3.6g fiber plus pectin (a prebiotic fiber) feeds beneficial gut bacteria. Raw crunch aids digestion.

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 35 is low. Fiber (3.6g) slows sugar absorption despite natural sweetness (6.1g sugar). Good choice.

bone_joint.insight: Vitamin A supports bone remodeling but low in calcium, vitamin D, and K. Not a bone-health superstar.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Excellent beta-carotene antioxidants fight inflammation. Good ORAC score. Low omega-3 but minimal omega-6.

vitaminA.tip: Beta-carotene absorbs better with fat—cook with oil or pair with hummus

pairWith.reason: Fat enhances beta-carotene absorption
Cooking with fat increases vitamin A absorption up to 6x
Healthy fats boost nutrient absorption

carrots.portionVisual: 1 cup chopped = about the size of a baseball

tips.storage: Refrigerate in a plastic bag for up to 3 weeks; remove greens if attached
tips.cooking: Eat raw for crunch or cook to increase beta-carotene bioavailability
tips.prepTip: Peel only if dirty—most nutrients are near the skin

commonMistakes: Eating without fat (limits vitamin A absorption)
Over-peeling removes nutrients near skin

cautions.carotenemia: Eating excessive amounts can turn skin orange (harmless but cosmetic)
cautions.allergies: Rare but can cross-react with birch pollen allergies

carrots.pregnancyNotes: Excellent—vitamin A supports fetal development. Don't overconsume (>10,000 IU/day can be harmful).

tomato.name: Tomato, raw
tomato.insight: A lycopene superstar—powerful antioxidant for heart and prostate health. Cooking actually increases lycopene bioavailability.

balanced.insight: Excellent vitamin C (28% DV), good potassium, and lycopene antioxidants. Very low calorie and naturally flavorful.

heart_health.insight: Outstanding lycopene reduces LDL oxidation. Good potassium (292mg), virtually no sodium. Excellent for heart health.

muscle_building.insight: Only 1.1g protein and 22 calories. Not for muscle building—just a healthy addition to meals.
pros: Lycopene may reduce exercise oxidative stress

energy.insight: Natural sugars (3.2g) provide quick energy but limited B-vitamins and calories. Better as a side than energy source.

weight_management.insight: Only 22 calories per tomato with high water content (94%). Satisfying and flavorful for minimal calories.

brain_focus.insight: Lycopene antioxidants protect brain cells and may reduce cognitive decline. Good vitamin C supports cognition.

gut_health.insight: 1.5g fiber plus high water content (94%) supports digestion. Easy to digest for most people.
cons: Acidic—may irritate sensitive stomachs or GERD

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 38 is low. Fiber slows sugar absorption despite natural sweetness (3.2g). Good for diabetics.

bone_joint.insight: Lycopene may benefit bone density but low in calcium, vitamin D, and K. Not a primary bone-health food.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Exceptional lycopene is one of the most powerful anti-inflammatory antioxidants. Excellent for reducing inflammation.

lycopene.tip: Cooking with oil increases lycopene absorption up to 4x—eat tomato sauce, not just raw

pairWith.reason: Fat dramatically increases lycopene absorption (cook into sauce)
Healthy fats enhance lycopene uptake
Classic pairing—fat helps absorb lycopene

tomato.portionVisual: 1 medium tomato = about the size of a tennis ball

tips.storage: Store at room temperature for best flavor; refrigerate only if very ripe
tips.cooking: Cook with oil to maximize lycopene absorption (sauce > raw)
tips.prepTip: Remove seeds if making sauce to reduce acidity and bitterness

commonMistakes: Eating raw without fat (limits lycopene absorption)
Refrigerating unripe tomatoes (ruins flavor and texture)

cautions.gerd: Acidic—may trigger acid reflux or heartburn in sensitive individuals
cautions.kidneyStones: Contains oxalates—moderate intake if prone to kidney stones
cautions.nightshades: Some people report sensitivity to nightshade vegetables

tomato.pregnancyNotes: Excellent choice—vitamin C and lycopene support fetal development. Wash thoroughly.

tomatoes.name: Tomatoes, raw
tomatoes.insight: A lycopene powerhouse—powerful antioxidant for heart and prostate health. Cooking actually increases lycopene bioavailability.

balanced.insight: Excellent vitamin C (41% DV), good potassium (427mg), and lycopene antioxidants. Very low calorie and naturally flavorful.

heart_health.insight: Outstanding lycopene reduces LDL oxidation. Good potassium (427mg), virtually no sodium. Excellent for heart health.

muscle_building.insight: Only 1.6g protein and 32 calories. Not for muscle building—just a healthy addition to meals.
pros: Lycopene may reduce exercise oxidative stress

energy.insight: Natural sugars (4.7g) provide quick energy but limited B-vitamins and calories. Better as a side than energy source.

weight_management.insight: Only 32 calories per cup with high water content (94%). Satisfying and flavorful for minimal calories.

brain_focus.insight: Lycopene antioxidants protect brain cells and may reduce cognitive decline. Good vitamin C supports cognition.

gut_health.insight: 2.2g fiber plus high water content (94%) supports digestion. Easy to digest for most people.
cons: Acidic—may irritate sensitive stomachs or GERD

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 38 is low. Fiber (2.2g) slows sugar absorption despite natural sweetness (4.7g). Good for diabetics.

bone_joint.insight: Lycopene may benefit bone density but low in calcium, vitamin D, and K. Not a primary bone-health food.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Exceptional lycopene is one of the most powerful anti-inflammatory antioxidants. Excellent for reducing inflammation.

lycopene.tip: Cooking with oil increases lycopene absorption up to 4x—eat tomato sauce, not just raw

tomatoes.portionVisual: 1 cup chopped = about the size of a baseball

tips.storage: Store at room temperature for best flavor; refrigerate only if very ripe
tips.cooking: Cook with oil to maximize lycopene absorption (sauce > raw)
tips.prepTip: Remove seeds if making sauce to reduce acidity and bitterness

commonMistakes: Eating raw without fat (limits lycopene absorption)
Refrigerating unripe tomatoes (ruins flavor and texture)

cautions.gerd: Acidic—may trigger acid reflux or heartburn in sensitive individuals
cautions.kidneyStones: Contains oxalates—moderate intake if prone to kidney stones

potato.name: Potato, flesh and skin, raw
potato.insight: A comfort food staple with excellent potassium (897mg, 26% DV) and vitamin C. High satiety but also high GI—eat skin for fiber.

balanced.insight: Good potassium (897mg, 26% DV), vitamin C (70% DV), and B6 (27% DV). High satiety but also high GI and carbs.
cons: Low in vitamins A, E, K

heart_health.insight: Outstanding potassium (897mg) supports blood pressure. Virtually no sodium and zero saturated fat. Good for heart.
cons: High GI may affect triglycerides if eaten in excess

muscle_building.insight: 4.3g protein is decent for a vegetable. 164 calories and 37g carbs make it good for refueling but not muscle-building alone.

energy.insight: 37g carbs provide sustained energy. Good B-vitamins (B6, niacin) support metabolism. High GI means quick energy but potential crash.
cons: High GI can cause energy crash

weight_management.insight: Very high satiety (91/100) thanks to resistant starch and fiber. However, 164 calories and high GI can lead to overeating.

brain_focus.insight: Excellent B6 (0.54mg, 27% DV) supports neurotransmitter synthesis. Good choline but high GI may cause energy fluctuations.
cons: High GI causes blood sugar swings

gut_health.insight: 4.7g fiber (with skin) plus resistant starch (when cooled) feeds beneficial gut bacteria. Good for microbiome.
cons: Must eat skin for full fiber

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 85 is very high. Spikes blood sugar rapidly. Fiber helps somewhat but not ideal for diabetics unless cooled and eaten with skin.

bone_joint.insight: Good magnesium and phosphorus for bone health but very low in calcium, vitamin D, and K. Not a bone-health superstar.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Moderate ORAC score with some antioxidants in skin. However, high GI and nightshade status may promote inflammation in some.

vitaminC.tip: Cooking destroys vitamin C—eat baked or steamed to preserve most

potassium.tip: Very bioavailable—one of the best potassium sources

pairWith.reason: Healthy fat slows digestion and lowers GI response
Protein and fat balance blood sugar and add satiety
Fiber and nutrients complement starchy potato

avoidWith.reason: Saturated fat adds unnecessary calories and negates heart benefits

potato.portionVisual: 1 medium potato = about the size of a computer mouse

tips.storage: Store in a cool, dark, dry place (not refrigerator); lasts 2-3 weeks
tips.cooking: Bake or steam to preserve nutrients; avoid frying. Eat the skin for fiber.
tips.prepTip: Cool after cooking to form resistant starch, which lowers GI and feeds gut bacteria

commonMistakes: Peeling removes most fiber and nutrients
Frying dramatically increases calories and negates health benefits
Eating alone without protein/fat causes blood sugar spike

cautions.greenPotatoes: Avoid green potatoes (contain toxic solanine)—discard if green or sprouted
cautions.nightshades: Some people report inflammation from nightshade vegetables
cautions.diabetes: High GI—eat in moderation and with skin/protein/fat

potato.pregnancyNotes: Good source of potassium and vitamin C. Avoid green potatoes (toxic solanine).

drugInteractions.reason: Very high potassium—monitor intake if on potassium-sparing drugs

pediatric.chokingRisk: low when cooked soft and mashed

baked_potato.name: Potato, baked, flesh and skin
baked_potato.insight: The highest satiety food ever tested (323/100)! Outstanding potassium (926mg) but very high GI (111). Eat with skin and pair with protein.

balanced.insight: Outstanding potassium (926mg, 27% DV) and exceptional satiety. However, very high GI (111) and moderate nutrient density.

heart_health.insight: Exceptional potassium (926mg) supports blood pressure. Virtually no sodium and zero saturated fat. High GI is only concern.
cons: Very high GI may affect triglycerides

muscle_building.insight: 4.3g protein is decent. 161 calories and 37g carbs make it excellent for post-workout glycogen replenishment.

energy.insight: 37g carbs provide quick energy but very high GI (111) means rapid spike and crash. Good B-vitamins for metabolism.

weight_management.insight: Highest satiety index ever tested (323/100)! However, 161 calories and very high GI can trigger overeating if not mindful.

brain_focus.insight: Excellent B6 (0.54mg, 27% DV) supports neurotransmitter synthesis. Very high GI causes blood sugar swings and brain fog.
cons: Very high GI causes energy crash

gut_health.insight: 3.8g fiber (with skin) plus resistant starch (if cooled and reheated) feeds gut bacteria. Good for microbiome.
cons: Must eat skin for full fiber

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 111 is extremely high—higher than pure glucose (100)! Spikes blood sugar rapidly. Avoid if diabetic unless with protein/fat.

bone_joint.insight: Good magnesium and phosphorus but very low in calcium, vitamin D, and K. Not a bone-health food.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Moderate antioxidants in skin but very high GI promotes inflammation. Nightshade status may affect sensitive individuals.

potassium.tip: Very bioavailable—one of the best potassium sources

vitaminC.tip: Baking destroys ~50% of vitamin C—eat soon after cooking

pairWith.reason: Protein and fat dramatically lower GI and add satiety
Fiber and nutrients balance the meal
Healthy fat slows digestion and lowers GI

avoidWith.reason: High in saturated fat and calories

baked_potato.portionVisual: 1 medium baked potato = about the size of a computer mouse

tips.storage: Refrigerate cooked potato for up to 5 days; cooling forms resistant starch (lowers GI)
tips.cooking: Bake at 425°F for 45-60 min; poke holes to vent steam
tips.prepTip: Eat the skin for fiber. Cool and reheat to form resistant starch (lowers GI by ~25%)

commonMistakes: Peeling removes most fiber and nutrients
Topping with butter/sour cream negates health benefits
Eating alone without protein/fat causes massive blood sugar spike

cautions.diabetes: Very high GI (111)—avoid or eat small portions with protein/fat
cautions.nightshades: Some report inflammation from nightshade vegetables
cautions.weight: Easy to overeat despite satiety—watch portions and toppings

baked_potato.pregnancyNotes: Excellent potassium source but monitor blood sugar. Eat with skin for folate.

drugInteractions.reason: Very high potassium—monitor intake if on potassium-sparing drugs

pediatric.chokingRisk: low when cooked soft and mashed

sweet_potato.name: Sweet potato, raw
sweet_potato.insight: A vitamin A superstar—one cup provides 286% DV from beta-carotene. Lower GI than white potato, naturally sweet, nutrient-dense.

balanced.insight: Outstanding vitamin A (1403mcg, 286% DV), good fiber (4g), and lower GI than white potato. Excellent nutrient density.

heart_health.insight: Good potassium (448mg), fiber (4g), and beta-carotene antioxidants support cardiovascular health. Very low saturated fat.

muscle_building.insight: 2.1g protein is low but 27g carbs make it good for post-workout glycogen replenishment. Good B6 for protein metabolism.

energy.insight: 27g carbs provide sustained energy. Good B-vitamins (B6, thiamin) support metabolism. Medium GI (63) = steady energy.

weight_management.insight: 114 calories per cup with high satiety (87/100) thanks to fiber (4g). Natural sweetness satisfies cravings without added sugar.

brain_focus.insight: Excellent B6 (0.28mg) and beta-carotene antioxidants protect brain cells. Medium GI provides steady glucose for cognition.

gut_health.insight: 4g fiber plus resistant starch (when cooled) feeds beneficial gut bacteria. Prebiotic benefits for microbiome.

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 63 is medium—much better than white potato (111). Fiber (4g) slows sugar absorption. Good choice for diabetics.

bone_joint.insight: Good magnesium and calcium but very low in vitamin D and K. Not a primary bone-health food.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Exceptional beta-carotene antioxidants fight inflammation. Good ORAC score. Much less inflammatory than white potato.

vitaminA.tip: Beta-carotene absorbs better with fat—cook with olive oil or eat with nuts

pairWith.reason: Fat enhances beta-carotene absorption up to 6x
May improve insulin sensitivity and enhance flavor
Complete the meal with lean protein

sweet_potato.portionVisual: 1 cup cubed = about the size of a baseball

tips.storage: Store in a cool, dark, dry place (not refrigerator); lasts 2-3 weeks
tips.cooking: Bake, roast, or steam to preserve nutrients; skin is edible and nutrient-rich
tips.prepTip: Don't peel—most nutrients are near the skin. Cool after cooking to form resistant starch.

commonMistakes: Adding marshmallows or brown sugar (negates health benefits)
Peeling removes fiber and nutrients
Eating without fat limits vitamin A absorption

cautions.kidneyStones: Contains oxalates—moderate intake if prone to calcium oxalate stones
cautions.diabetes: Medium GI—monitor portions and pair with protein/fat

sweet_potato.pregnancyNotes: Excellent—outstanding vitamin A (but not toxic preformed retinol) supports fetal development.

pediatric.chokingRisk: low when cooked soft and mashed

yam.name: Yam, raw
yam.insight: A potassium powerhouse (1224mg, 35% DV) with excellent fiber (5.3g). Lower GI than white potato, less sweet than sweet potato.

balanced.insight: Outstanding potassium (1224mg, 35% DV), excellent fiber (5.3g), and good vitamin C (39% DV). Well-rounded starchy vegetable.

heart_health.insight: Exceptional potassium (1224mg) supports blood pressure. Excellent fiber (5.3g), virtually no sodium. Outstanding for heart health.

muscle_building.insight: Only 2g protein but 37g carbs make it good for post-workout glycogen replenishment. Excellent potassium for muscle function.

energy.insight: 37g carbs provide sustained energy. Good B-vitamins (B6, thiamin) support metabolism. Low GI (54) = steady energy.

weight_management.insight: 158 calories per cup with high satiety (89/100) thanks to excellent fiber (5.3g). Filling and nutrient-dense.

brain_focus.insight: Excellent B6 (0.4mg) and potassium (1224mg) support cognition. Low GI provides steady glucose without crashes.

gut_health.insight: Excellent fiber (5.3g) plus resistant starch (when cooled) feeds beneficial gut bacteria. Outstanding for microbiome.

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 54 is low. Excellent fiber (5.3g) and minimal sugar (0.8g). Much better than white potato for diabetics.

bone_joint.insight: Good magnesium and phosphorus but very low in calcium, vitamin D, and K. Not a bone-health food.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Good vitamin C and moderate ORAC score. Low GI helps reduce inflammation. Decent anti-inflammatory profile.

potassium.tip: Very bioavailable—one of the best potassium sources

vitaminC.tip: Cook minimally to preserve vitamin C

pairWith.reason: Traditional pairing—fat slows digestion
Complete the meal with protein and fiber
Add vitamins A and K that yam lacks

yam.portionVisual: 1 cup cubed = about the size of a baseball

tips.storage: Store in a cool, dark, dry place; lasts 2-3 weeks (do not refrigerate)
tips.cooking: Boil, bake, or roast until tender; skin is edible but thick
tips.prepTip: Cool after cooking to form resistant starch for lower GI and gut benefits

commonMistakes: Confusing with sweet potato (different species, different nutrients)
Over-peeling removes fiber
Eating alone without protein/fat

cautions.rawConsumption: Must be cooked—raw yams contain toxic compounds
cautions.diabetes: Moderate GI—monitor portions and pair with protein

yam.pregnancyNotes: Excellent potassium source. Must be thoroughly cooked (never eat raw).

drugInteractions.reason: Very high potassium—monitor intake if on potassium-sparing drugs

pediatric.chokingRisk: low when cooked soft and mashed

onion.name: Onion, raw
onion.insight: A quercetin powerhouse with potent anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial compounds. Sulfur compounds support detoxification and heart health.

balanced.insight: Good fiber (1.9g) and quercetin antioxidants. Very low calorie (44) and virtually no sodium. Modest vitamin content.

heart_health.insight: Outstanding quercetin reduces blood pressure and LDL oxidation. Sulfur compounds support arterial health. Virtually no sodium.

muscle_building.insight: Only 1.2g protein and 44 calories. Not for muscle building—just a flavorful ingredient.
pros: Quercetin may reduce inflammation from exercise

energy.insight: Natural sugars (4.7g) provide minimal energy. Limited B-vitamins and calories. Better for flavor than fuel.

weight_management.insight: Only 44 calories per medium onion with good flavor and fiber. Adds taste without adding calories.

brain_focus.insight: Outstanding quercetin antioxidants protect brain cells and may reduce cognitive decline. Sulfur compounds support detox.

gut_health.insight: 1.9g fiber plus prebiotic fructans feed beneficial gut bacteria. Quercetin supports gut lining health.
cons: FODMAPs may cause gas in sensitive individuals

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 10 is extremely low. Quercetin may improve insulin sensitivity. Minimal impact on blood sugar.

bone_joint.insight: Quercetin may reduce inflammation in joints but very low in calcium, vitamin D, and K. Not a bone-health food.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Exceptional quercetin is one of the most potent anti-inflammatory plant compounds. Excellent ORAC score.

quercetin.tip: Pair with fat or cook briefly to enhance quercetin absorption

pairWith.reason: Fat enhances quercetin absorption
Complementary allium compounds amplify health benefits
Classic pairing with complementary antioxidants

onion.portionVisual: 1 medium onion = about the size of a tennis ball

tips.storage: Store in a cool, dry place away from potatoes; lasts 2-3 months
tips.cooking: Brief cooking preserves quercetin; long cooking reduces it. Red onions have most quercetin.
tips.prepTip: Let chopped onions sit 5-10 min before cooking to maximize allicin formation

commonMistakes: Overcooking destroys quercetin and sulfur compounds
Storing near potatoes (they release gases that spoil each other)

cautions.fodmap: High in fructans—avoid if sensitive to FODMAPs or have IBS
cautions.allergies: Rare but can cause contact dermatitis
cautions.rawConsumption: Raw onions may irritate sensitive stomachs

onion.pregnancyNotes: Safe in food amounts. Quercetin and folate support fetal development.

drugInteractions.reason: May have mild anticoagulant effects—likely safe in food amounts

pediatric.ageAppropriate: 8+ months cooked, 12+ months raw in small amounts
pediatric.chokingRisk: low when cooked soft or minced
